question_details.title: Which party will win the most seats in the Storting in the 2025 Norwegian election? (Liberal)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-12-10 13:13:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/20174). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

In [2021’s elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Norwegian_parliamentary_election), The center-left [Labour Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(Norway)) won the most seats with 48 out of the 169 seats in the [Storting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storting) and formed a minority government with the centrist [Centre Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_Party_(Norway)).

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":20174,"question_id":20181}}`
question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'Liberal'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

The party which wins the highest number of seats in the Storting in the first Norwegian parliamentary general election that occurs after November 25, 2023, and before September 30, 2025, will resolve as Yes. All other parties will resolve as No. If two parties have the same number of seats, both of them will resolve as Yes. If a party which is not listed wins the highest number of seats, all questions will resolve as No.

**Election in Norway returns Labour to power, as far-right Progress Party doubles vote share**
Norway's general election on 12 September 2025 saw the governing Labour Party (AP) win 28.0 % of the vote and 53 of the 169 seats in the Storting, giving the left bloc a majority with 88 seats. The far‑right Progress Party (FRP) doubled its share to about 24 %. Prime Minister‑elect Jonas Gahr Støre will seek either a coalition with the other left parties or outside support for a minority AP government. The four smaller left‑bloc parties – Centre (SP), Socialist Left (SV), Red and Greens (MDG) – together hold 35 % of the seats. The article notes that the parties approved a 12‑year military‑spending plan that will add 600 bn kroner (≈ €50 bn) to the defence budget, including 136 bn kroner for five frigates, and a new Arctic strategy “Norway in the North”. It also reports that the government will provide 85 bn kroner to Ukraine in 2025. The GPFG, valued at €1.7 trillion, is capped at 3 % annual spending, so the war‑related budget is funded at the expense of public services. Energy prices hit a record high in December 2024, and Labour’s popularity fell to 14 % in polls. The Centre Party left the coalition, dropping from 13 % in 2021 to 5.6 %. Støre appointed former NATO Secretary‑General Jens Stoltenberg as Finance Minister and introduced a “Norway price” of 0.4 kroner per kWh, effective 1 October. Trade Union Confederation (LO) leader Kine Asper Vistnes praised the result, saying 'Our social model is based on freedom, equality, and solidarity, and it has proven itself well equipped to handle crises and transitions.' The article criticises the right‑wing parties for supporting NATO militarism and war, and portrays the new government as likely to deepen Norway’s involvement in the conflict with Russia. It also quotes NHO head Ole Erik Almlid saying 'I am sure that ways can be found to cooperate well with both the Storting and government in the future.'

**Stoltenberg's Victory, Putin's Friends' Failure: What Norway's Elections Show**
The 8 September 2025 Norwegian parliamentary election saw the Labour Party win 53 seats, five more than before, but still short of the 85 seats needed for an outright majority.  Labour will form a minority government with the support of left‑wing parties – the Centre Party, Socialists, the ‘Red’ party (Rødt) and the Greens – which together hold 88 votes, giving the coalition a working majority.  Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre said he would meet with these partners in the coming days, noting, 'We have a lot in common and we will find good solutions.'  Finance Minister Yngve Stoltenberg, whose appointment has bolstered Støre’s credibility, added, 'I am very motivated to continue this work.'  The election also highlighted the rise of right‑wing forces: the Progress Party secured 23.8% of the vote and 47 seats, the highest result in its history, while the Conservative Party fell to 14.6% and 47 seats, its worst in 20 years.  The article frames the Progress Party’s platform as ‘ultra‑right’ and criticises the Conservatives for failing to mobilise voters, describing the result as a ‘failure’ for them.  Russian influence was mentioned, noting that the pro‑Russian party ‘For Peace and Justice’ received only 0.3% of the vote and that the Norwegian sovereign wealth fund faced scrutiny over investments in Israeli‑linked companies.  Overall, the piece presents the election outcome and subsequent coalition negotiations, while casting a negative light on right‑wing parties and Russian‑aligned groups.

**NORWEGIAN ELECTIONS: DOMESTIC CHALLENGES AND FOREIGN POLICY PARADOXES**
Norway’s parliamentary elections on 8 September 2025 confirmed the ruling Labour Party’s strong position, winning 28.2 % of the vote. Prime Minister Jonas Gahr Støre said, 'This is a signal to the world that social democracy can win too, despite the right‑wing wave.' The Progress Party, led by Sylvie Listhaug, achieved a historic 23.8 % and 47 seats—26 more than in 2021—and Listhaug declared, 'It's fantastic. Our results are better than the polls showed. So it's incredibly good. We still have reason to consider ourselves winners.' The Conservative Party fell to third place with 14.6 % and 24 seats, a loss of 12 seats. The Socialist Left and Centre parties each secured 9 seats (5.6 % of the vote). The Red‑Green bloc retained a majority, enabling a government. The Red Party won 5.3 % and 9 seats; the Green Party increased to 8 seats with 4.7 %. Christian Democrats and Liberal Party received 7 and 3 seats respectively. Turnout was 79.9 %. Despite domestic shifts, Norway will continue to support Ukraine and enforce EU sanctions against Russia, driven by its role as a major energy supplier. The campaign focused on climate and energy, with the Green Party opposing new drilling projects. The article also critiques U.S. President Donald Trump’s approach, quoting him: 'We will send them [Ukraine] some Patriot complexes – they really need them. They will pay one hundred per cent for it – and that's exactly what we're seeking.'

The 2025 Norwegian parliamentary election saw the red‑green coalition – Labour, the Green Party (MDG) and the Red Party (Rødt) – win a majority with about 89 seats, compared with 80 for the centre‑right bloc. The Labour Party’s Kine Asper Vistnes welcomed the outcome, stating, 'Rødgrønn side har vunnet valget.'
